ygData.subject: Re: Crossover doing anything in HyperNEAT and PNEAT?
ygData.msgSnippet: Jason and I are going to look over the crossover operator and sort it out to work like original NEAT.  We aim to have word back to the group shortly. ken ...

out t=
o work like original NEAT.  We aim to have word back to the group
shortly.

ok worse than with the old way; however, I think that the mutation

need to be tweaked because now mutations in individuals quickly

roughout the species.
>

 and see if I can get

rk better without
> performing crossover on each gene.

ow what I find out.

> > > The questio=
n about crossover in NEAT is interesting.  Although
it does
> > > not provi=
de a huge boost in performance, it is still a significant
> > > advance com=
pared to what came before in neuroevolution, which is why
> > > it is still=
 a payoff.  The competing conventions problem (also
called
> > > the "topol=
ogy matching problem") was a huge issue in neuroevolution
> > > before NEAT=
, and because of it some researchers were questioning
> > > whether there w=
as any hope for crossover at all in such systems.  It
> > > could be shown =
in prior systems without historical marking that
> > > crossover actually h=
urts the evolution of neural networks,
making its
> > > prospects dim.  Ang=
eline and Pollack even introduced a
neuroevolution
> > > method called GNAR=
L (before NEAT) that didn't even have crossover as
> > > an operator becaus=
e of the concern.  In this context, NEAT made
> > > crossover safe for neur=
oevolution and removed its stigma in such
> > > systems.  That is, it switc=
hed it from a liability to an advantage
> > > that boosts performance a bit=
 in NEAT.  So it's an advance in that
> sense.
> > > 
> > > However, while =
the "bit" of performance gain (vs. having no
crossover)
> > > *is* likely s=
tatistically significant, it is not huge.  The real
> > > benefit of histor=
ical markings
> > > is that it enables speciation, which does have a dramat=
ic effect
> > > because of protecting innovation to support complexificatio=
n.
> > > Crossover is more like icing on the cake.  However, I think many
>=
 > > people identify NEAT with crossover because it is such a clear
> > > d=
emonstration of the benefit of historical markings.  In that sense,
> > > i=
t is perhaps conceptually more significant than it is functionally.
> > > S=
till, I would recommend keeping it if you can, since it does appear
> > > t=
o be better to have it than not, albeit not enormously.
> > > 
> > > ken
> =
> >

me, however. Isn't one of the hallmarks of NEAT the
> > >> intelligent cros=
sover via historical markings? I guess I just
> > > assumed that
> > >> had=
 been shown to provide a huge payoff. If crossover doesn't help
> > > that =
much
> > >> in NEAT, how much does *intelligent* (vs. na=EF=BF=BDve) crosso=
ver help?

at P-NEAT is just NEAT with additive mutations

 in principle crossover should choose genes
> > > randomly
> > >>>>>>>>> fr=
om both parents as it builds the offspring genome, the

> > =
>>>>>>>>> HyperNEAT the crossover is different, there you actually
do a
> >=
 >>>>>>> regular
> > >>>>>>>>> NEAT evolution of networks that build other =
networks based
> > > on the
> > >>>>>>>>> substrate configuration. That is,=
 you only mate and
mutate the
> > >>>>>>> CPPNs.
> > >>>>>>>>> But in the c=
ase you get lots of individuals with equal
> > > fitness, I
> > >>>>>>>>> g=
uess these individuals are clones. Perhaps the code
> frequently
> > >>>>>>=
>>> chooses the same individuals for mating? You can try to
> > > avoid thi=
s
> > >>>>>>> by
> > >>>>>>>>> introducing a loop in which you try candidat=
es for a
> > > "father" that
> > >>>>>>> are
> > >>>>>>>>> not compatible w=
ith the mother, that is, when their
> > > compatibility
> > >>>>>>>>> dista=
nce is 0.00, try again. There is another possibility,
> > > simply
> > >>>>=
>>>>> every mutation disturbs the CPPN and therefore the produced
> > >>>>>=
>> network is
> > >>>>>>>>> changed in such a magnitude that is has no chan=
ce for
> > > survival and
> > >>>>>>> is
> > >>>>>>>>> discarded. Even thou=
gh there is speciation.

@> wrote:
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>>>>>>>> Hello all-

>>>>>>> Does crossover do anything in PNEAT and HyperNEAT?
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
=
> > >>>>>>>>>> PNEAT:
> > >>>>>>>>>> If I am reading the code correctly, du=
ring crossover,
if the
> > >>>>>>>>> substrates are
> > >>>>>>>>>> the same=
 (i.e. all links have the same ID), which is
> always the
> > >>>>>>> case
=
> > >>>>>>>>> in
> > >>>>>>>>>> P-NEAT, *all* of the link values are taken =
from either
> > > parent1 or
> > >>>>>>>>> parent2.
> > >>>>>>>>>> Isn't it=
 more normal when crossing over to take some from
> > > parent1
> > >>>>>>>=
>> and some
> > >>>>>>>>>> from parent2? Why grab all from just one?
> > >>=
>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>>>>>>>> This means that in PNEAT crossover does nothing, r=
ight?
> It will
> > >>>>>>>>> always grab
> > >>>>>>>>>> the substrate of p=
arent1 or the substrate of parent2.  If I
> > > track
> > >>>>>>>>> parent =
and
> > >>>>>>>>>> offspring fitness, 100% of the time the child has the ex=
act
> > > same
> > >>>>>>>>> fitness as
> > >>>>>>>>>> one of the two paren=
ts.
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>>>>>>>> On to HyperNEAT:
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>=
>>>>>>> I tracked the fitness of each parent and the resulting
> > > offspr=
ing.
> > >>>>>>>>> The odd
> > >>>>>>>>>> thing is that the organisms that =
are crossed only (i.e.
> > > they are
> > >>>>>>>>> never
> > >>>>>>>>>> mu=
tated) have the *exact* same fitness of one of their
> parents
> > >>>>>>>>=
> 98.88% of the
> > >>>>>>>>>> time. In 20 runs, that was only 136 orgs out=
 of 12257
> that were
> > >>>>>>>>> crossed over
> > >>>>>>>>>> and not mut=
ated. That seems wrong, doesn't it? Why would
> these
> > >>>>>>> new
> > >=
>>>>>>>> links
> > >>>>>>>>>> have such a small impact? It turns out that t=
his is because
> > >>>>>>> nearly
> > >>>>>>>>> every
> > >>>>>>>>>> time t=
hat there is an extra link that gets placed in the
> child,
> > >>>>>>> the=

> > >>>>>>>>> parent
> > >>>>>>>>>> that donated that link is also the par=
ent whose weights are
> > > being
> > >>>>>>>>> grabbed,
> > >>>>>>>>>> mea=
ning that the crossover is only copying the parent
> > > (hence the
> > >>>=
>>>>>> same
> > >>>>>>>>>> fitness). It seems to me that crossover should b=
e much more
> > >>>>>>>>> disruptive, no?
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>>>>>>>> 
>=
 > >>>>>>>>>> As a final test, I did a set of hyperneat and pneat runs
> > =
> with the
> > >>>>>>>>> default
> > >>>>>>>>>> 'MutateOnlyProbability' par=
ameter set to .25, so 25% of
orgs
> > >>>>>>> never
> > >>>>>>>>> are
> > >=
>>>>>>>>> candidates for crossover. I then ran experimental
treatments
> > =
>>>>>>>>>> hyperneat-noCross and pneat-noCross where the
> > >>>>>>> Mutate=
OnlyProbability
> > >>>>>>>>>> parameter was set to 1, so no orgs were cros=
sed over.
> > > Despite my
> > >>>>>>>>> comments
> > >>>>>>>>>> above, Hyp=
erneat (with cross) did beat HyperNEAT-noCross,
> > > however
> > >>>>>>>>>=
 the
> > >>>>>>>>>> difference was not tremendous (although it does seem to=
 be
> > >>>>>>>>> statistically
> > >>>>>>>>>> significant). For p-neat, th=
e reverse was true.
Nevertheless,
> > >>>>>>> this
> > >>>>>>>>> is not a
>=
 > >>>>>>>>>> perfect test of whether crossover pays dividends,
because if
=
> > >>>>>>>>> crossover does
> > >>>>>>>>>> nothing most of the time, and I=
 increase
> MutateOnlyProbability
> > >>>>>>> from
> > >>>>>>>>> .25 to
> >=
 >>>>>>>>>> 1, I have effectively raised the mutation rate (only 80% of
> >=
 >>>>>>> crossed
> > >>>>>>>>> orgs are
> > >>>>>>>>>> also mutated).
> > >=
>>>>>>>>> 
> > >>>>>>>>>> Are these the intended consequences of crossover,=
 or am I

> > >>>>>>>>> something?
